Helen Keller.Action: Emits a bleat (sound) as a baby but shows vitality despite illness.
Screams sharply in distress, showing a strong, expressive response.
Makes a knifing scream that alarms adults.
Shows no visible reaction to sound or sight stimuli (does not blink or respond).
Moves slowly and erratically.
Reaches out and lashes out in fear, becomes tangled in sheets and almost hysterical.
Rips down Christmas decorations, shattering them at her feet while other children watch.
Flanks other children and tries to participate by feeling their lips and mouths, showing an attempt to communicate and engage.
Hands thrust abruptly and insistently at others' faces, showing lack of restraint and no smiles or friendly facial expressions.
Topples Martha onto her back, pins her shoulders down, and grabs the scissors from her hair, resisting efforts to be controlled.
Bites at her own fingers in a bizarre rage while trying to communicate.
Struggles with Kate over scissors but manages to keep hold of them, showing physical assertiveness and control.
Trying to talk silently but growing frantic and unable to clearly communicate.
Pulls the scissors back in a struggle and refuses to give them up, showing determination and control over the object.

Surrenders the scissors when Kate gently guides her and points toward the house; obediently follows Kate toward the door and scrambles up toward the house, indicating responsiveness and ability to follow directions.
Halts and her hands are alert to grope when presented with the doll, showing engagement and curiosity in the new object.
Sits gravely exploring the doll with her fingers, searching for features on a blank face, showing curiosity and sincere engagement.
Taps her eyes repeatedly, trying to communicate with others though no one notices or understands.
Paws papers off the desk in exasperation, indicating frustration but no aggression or hostility.
Sits solemnly and touches the doll's face, attempting to understand it with her fingers.
Pauses and searches carefully for features on the doll's face, showing curiosity and analytical behavior.
Taps her eyes repeatedly to gain attention, but no one understands her.
Paws through papers on the desk angrily, scattering them on the floor, showing frustration but also agency.
Fingers her dress, yanks two buttons from it, and pushes the buttons into the doll's face as eyes.
Rocks the doll, pats it vigorously, kisses it, expressing joy for the doll having eyes.
Suddenly scrambles toward the cradle and unhesitatingly overturns it.
Yanks two buttons from her dress, then pushes them into the doll's face to make eyes.
Nods energetically to indicate she wants the doll to have eyes, showing understanding and purposeful communication.
Cannot contain her joy when the doll finally has eyes; rocks, pats, and kisses it vigorously.
Scrambles suddenly toward the cradle and unhesitatingly overturns it.
Lies her doll gently in the cradle after overturning it, unperturbed by the commotion.
Her fingers flutter to her mother's lips, trying to comprehend their movements, showing a desire to connect.
Strikes at her mother's lips and begins to kick and struggle out of frustration.
Struggles violently, blunders away, collides with a chair, falls and sits weeping after being released.
